page.title: 20BORDON TRANSPORT.
page.content: William Cobbett travelled through Woolmer Forest in 1817 on a coach road which is now called Forest Road. Ten years later a turnpike road linking Aldershot to Petersfield passed through Bordon and in 1865 a road from Longmoor to the west of Bordon was built. In 1903 the War Dept. transferred 60 army huts from Longmoor to Bordon Camp and built a narrow guage railway for this purpose. It was converted to a military training railway and eventually linked Bordon to Liss and then to Portsmouth.Around the same time the Bordon to Bentley line was built.They functioned mainly as supply lines to Bordon Camp but also carried passengers.Both lines were closed by 1968 but the area is well serviced by buses to Liphook, Aldershot,Petersfield and Basingstoke. However most people travel by car.
